Administration of Intravenous (iv) Iodinated Contrast Media in the Radiology Department/16031/2.1
Appendix 1: Appendix 2: Appendix 3: Appendix 4: Appendix 5: Appendix 6: Appendix 7: Appendix 8: Appendix 9:
Central line flow chart
Patient Questionnaire

PICC line testing with the covidien pump
A look-up table to show volumes for portal venous imaging
A look-up table to show fixed volumes for listed CT examinations Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
To provide a written procedure for staff undertaking Intravenous (IV) Injection of contrast media.
To identify the risk groups associated with IV iodinated Contrast Media (CM) and to outline steps of reducing risk.
To keep the number of iodinated CM reactions as low as practically possible.

Steps have been made to ensure this policy complies with The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists Iodinated Contrast Media Guidance 2018 (RANZCR), as adopted by the Royal College of Radiologists (RCR), and the Society and College of Radiographers (SCoR).
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospitals is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 9)
Infection Prevention and Control
All staff should follow trust guidelines on infection prevention and control. It is particularly important to ensure hands are decontaminated before and after contact with each patient.
Aims
To ensure a high-quality service is provided to the end service user.
To improve patient safety.
To reduce the number of associated adverse reactions.
To reduce the number of extravasations.
To reduce the risk of infection.
To prevent delays.
Training
All radiographers who perform IV cannulation must have completed a
"Certificate of Competence in Administering Intravenous Injections". This form of university based qualification must be awarded by an institution that has been
accredited by the College of Radiographers (CoR). In house legacy training will
be recognised.
During the training, the Radiographer must evidence a minimum number of injections including:
Ten (supervised minimum assistance) injections;
Twenty (supervised no assistance) injections.
The Radiographer must have attended Basic Life Support (BLS) training. This local, mandatory training course also requires attending a refresher programme every two years as per trust policy.
Scope and Responsibilities

The target audience for this policy includes the radiographers and radiologists as justifiers of the examinations and administrators of IV contrast media. This guidance should also be used by clinicians who refer patients for examinations involving IV contrast.
When required, advice should always be taken from a Radiologist and documented accordingly on the Radiology Information System (RIS).
Contrast media should only be administered when clinically indicated [Refer to 9.0 + 11.0]

An individual trained in recognising and treating contrast media reactions should be immediately available in the department where contrast is administered and must be contactable. In hours this is expected to be the duty radiologist (unless otherwise agreed), and contrast CT examinations should only occur out of hours, if a doctor is present.
Radiographers should not proceed with IV cannulation when patients are under the age of 18 nor must they inject intravenous contrast media. The Patient Group
Directive (PGD) strictly excludes radiographers administrating IV contrast media in these cases. In these circumstances the radiologist or referring doctor should be
responsible for IV access and contrast administration when required.
All healthcare and medical professionals have a responsibility to adhere to the principles described in this policy/guideline.
Equipment
The following equipment must be checked each morning before a patient enters the room:
Emergency equipment (Crash Trolley)
7.2.1 This should be the first port of call for reactions that need managing immediately and for any reactions that are moderate to severe in severity.
7.2.2 This trolley must be readily available when required for fast retrieval.
7.2.3 1 x Crash Trolley in CT01 Prep room and 1 x Crash Trolley in CT02 Prep room; this contains:
Epinephrine (Adrenaline) in 1,000 (1ml) marked “FOR ANAPHYLAXIS” (Box);
Epinephrine (Adrenaline) Prefilled syringe 1:10,000 in 10ml;
Amiodarone Prefilled syringe 30mg/ml in 10ml;
Atropine Sulfate Prefilled syringe 3mg in 10ml;
Calcium Chloride Prefilled syringe 10% w/v in 10ml;
Magnesium Sulfate 50% (1g in 2ml);
Sodium bicarbonate 8.4% (10mmol in 10ml);
Glucose 20% 500ml.
Drug Tray
7.3.1 This must be readily available. (Located in locked CT01 storeroom - in labelled drug cupboard)
7.3.2 This contains:
NaCl 0.9% 5ml;
Water for injections (2ml and 10ml);
Hydrocortisone as sodium succinate (Solu-Cortef 100mg);
Chlorphenamine (Piriton) 4mg tablets (Oral administration);
Chlorphenamine Solution for Injection (10mg in 1ml);
Selection of needles;
2ml and 10ml syringes.
Other emergency equipment
The following equipment should also be available in the vicinity
Portable/Piped oxygen - including mask, tubing and scissors;
Suction - with suction tubing and a sterile yankauer pre attached);
IV Trolley - with a selection of syringes, needles, gloves, swabs;
Crash Trolley - all contents must be checked weekly and the crash trolley seal should be checked on a daily basis as per trust protocol.
Cannulation equipment (cannulation tray)
19g (Blue) /21g (Pink) Venflon / Cannula;
Tourniquet, Tape, Gauze Swab;
Chloraprep applicator;
Saline (≦ 5mls for flushing);
Syringe (10ml);
Drawing up needle.
Cannulation equipment (contrast warming cabinet)

7.6.1  Warmed non-ionic contrast to body temperature (36.5 - 37.5 °C) should be used. The maximum and minimum temperatures of the contrast warmer should be monitored and recorded in a temperature log, and contrast must be labelled with the date it is
placed into the warmer. It should not be stored in this way for longer than 30 days
(RANZCR Page 27).
Power Injector Pump
This must be fully functional and in a serviceable condition. Power injectors are routinely serviced on a yearly basis and service records are kept in CT.
Prescribing CM

The requirement of contrast media for a CT scan must be made clear, after the request has been justified by a radiologist or by a vetting radiographer (following a written protocol agreed by the radiologists). This will be made explicit in the form of selecting the appropriate protocol number on the Radiology Information System (RIS) which is available for the Radiographers to view.
For a radiographer to administer contrast media, the Patient Group Directive (PGD) must be followed. It is important to note the exclusions of the PGD.

When the PGD is excluded, contrast media must be prescribed by a medical doctor. In hours, this will be the radiologist covering the duty session. There must be documented evidence provided on the RIS system to support the decisions made by the Consultant justifying the contrast media being given.

Out of hours, the responsibility lies with the referring clinician/clinician escorting the patient to prescribe and administer IV contrast media. In all cases the doctor must follow the advice and instruction from the out of hours Radiologist (Everlight) when the call is initially made for the scan to be accepted.
If the administration of contrast media needs to be repeated please consult with the supervising radiologist and refer to the manufacture guidelines to prevent overdose.
Request Forms
Radiology requests must be made on the Lorenzo system and include all of the
patient's demographic information plus the bleep number of the referrer. This point of contact is particularly important if the referrer is needed in an emergency, or if they
are required to administer IV contrast media out of hours. It is also useful in situations
where the request needs to be discussed by the duty Radiologist.
The referrer must provide sufficient clinical details in order to justify the CT scan.
The referrer should also highlight whether a patient has poor renal function,
hyperthyroidism or history of a previous contrast media reaction on the request,
as these factors could prevent contrast media administration and in some
circumstances could stop the CT scan from going ahead. Further to this, Oncologists should indicate if a patient is taking the Interleukin-2 drug.
Immediate Pre Checks
Three forms of ID must be checked (e.g. full name, date of birth, address or hospital number) in addition to the clinical details by the injecting radiographer.
The requirement of IV Contrast media must be checked (refer to section 9.0) by the radiographer prior to administering the contrast.
The radiographer is responsible for explaining the examination to the patient including the reason for intravenous injection.

To proceed, the patient must give consent. The individual administering the contrast media must ensure that the patient understands why it is to be given and the patient must agree to the procedure. They will be asked to sign the patient questionnaire as evidence of consent (Appendix 2). If the patient is not able to cognitively make a decision a MCA2 form must be in place [as per trust protocol].
The radiographer must also check for risk of pregnancy in females of child bearing age (following local protocol).

Nuclear Medicine (NM) isotope thyroid imaging scans should be avoided for 8 weeks after IV administration of contrast media (RANZCR Page 21). It is therefore advised that RIS is checked for any outstanding NM scans prior to their CM scan. If the patient has an outstanding scheduled NM scan then the decision to give IV contrast media should be made by the referring clinician.
Patient Questionnaire

See Appendix 2 for a copy of the patient questionnaire. This should be used for both outpatients and inpatients. Patient questionnaires should be taken from the patient on arrival and scanned onto the RIS system as an electronic record.
CM checks in the Department – Identifying Risk Groups
Is the patient hyperthyroid?
According to RANZCR “Patients with known or suspected hyperthyroidism (clinical or biochemical) should be tested and treated for this in consultation with the referrer or
an endocrinologist prior to contrast media administration.” Page
Does the patient have thyroid cancer?
Use of contrast media will preclude therapeutic radio-iodine treatment for 8 weeks
(RANZCR Page 21)
The following risk factors must also be checked in the department prior to Injection to highlight those at increased risk and therefore minimise the risk of
adverse events. This essential informationincludes:
Previous contrast reaction sensitivity to iodine-based CM;
Asthma (If yes, is it well controlled?);
Renal problems;
Diabetes mellitus;
Metformin therapy;
Current use of Beta-adrenergic blockers;
Previous significant allergic reactions to other substances or history of eczema (RANZCR Page 11).
Is the patient on Interleukin-2-treatment?
There is limited evidence to suggest that IV contrast media will cause an increased
risk of delayed anaphylactic reaction in patients who are receiving this treatment.
RANZCR recommends patients who are currently taking IL-2 therapy or who have
completed treatment within the past 6 months are advised of the mild increase in the risk of delayed anaphylactic contrast reaction. No further precautions are advised. (refer to RANZCR page 23).
Shellfish or topical iodine reaction?
There is no specific cross reactivity (RANZCR Page 11).
Does the patient have multiple well-documented allergies? (or) a single severe allergy?
If yes, the patient is at a higher risk of reaction.
In the presence of any of the risk factors [Above] the decision about contrast media administration should be taken only by the radiologist supervising the procedure.
In cases where there is history of a moderately severe or severe reaction, other
potential methods of investigation or un-enhanced study should be considered.

12.7.1 The RANZCR guidelines recommend that in high risk patient's, the cannula is kept in situ for 30 mins and the patient observed during this time. If known in advance of the appointment, these patients can be prescribed prednisolone steroid cover to be taken orally at 13 hours and 1 hour before the contrast injection. (RANZCR Page 12.)
Breastfeeding
The RANZCR guidelines state that cessation of breast feeding or expression and discarding of breast milk after IV contrast media is not required (refer to RANZCR page 23).
Pregnant females

If the scan is justified by the radiologist to go ahead and if administering IV contrast media is necessary, thyroid function should be measured in the first week after birth due to the small theoretical risk of thyroid suppression in the foetus. This is done
routinely in every newborn using the heel prick technique.
Reference should also be made to the patient questionnaire [Appendix 2] and
advice from a radiologist should be sought if there are any concerns or if the patient has answered yes to any of the questions.
Blood tests/Renal Function
Patients with poor renal function should be discussed with the duty radiologist prior to referral to the department
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR)
13.2.1 eGFR is the preferred way of determining kidney function than serum creatinine
alone and should always be sought where possible. The greatest risk of
contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI) is in patients with an eGFR of 30 or less (refer to RANZCR page 14).
13.2.2 The RANZCR recommendations are as follows:

Intravascular iodinated contrast media should be given to any patient regardless of renal function status if the perceived diagnostic benefit to the patient, in the opinion of the radiologist and the referrer, justifies this administration;

Emergency imaging procedures requiring contrast media administration e.g. acute stroke, acute bleeding, trauma etc. should not be delayed in order to obtain renal function testing results prior to the procedure;

In patients with severe renal function impairment (eGFR less than  ml/min/1.73m2) or actively deteriorating renal function (acute kidney injury) careful weighing of the risk versus the benefit of iodinated contrast media administration needs to be undertaken. Consideration should be given to peri-procedural renal protection using intravenous hydration with 0.9% saline. However, severe renal function impairment should not be regarded as an absolute contraindication to medically indicated iodinated contrast media administration;
For patients who are at higher risk of CI- AKI, pre and post procedural 0.9% IV saline is recommended as the first line preventive strategy to mitigate the risk of CI-AKI (refer to RANCZR page 19).
Renal bloods should be within:
3 months (if pt in a stable condition);
7 days (if the patient has an acute illness or known renal disease).
Patients receiving iodinated contrast media who have an eGFR
below 30 ml/min/1.73 m are considered to be at a higher risk of acute kidney Injury.
ABOVE >/= 30 ml/min/1.73 m = IV Contrast media can be administered
(after pre-checks and departmental checks have been cleared
BELOW m = IV Contrast media is not routinely recommended. Seek radiologist guidance.
If dialysis has been organised by the referrer, it must be performed within
hours of the contrast media to reduce the risk of kidney injury.
When Bloods are not Available
The vetting Radiographer checks patient's blood results are available 3 days prior to the appointment. In the event these are not available on the Review System, the
Radiology appointments team are asked to contact the patient to see if they have a
blood form, or have had the bloods done at a different NHS trust. A blood form can
be issued by the appointments staff if necessary, or patient's asked to bring a copy of
their results to their appointment if they have been taken elsewhere.
In emergency situations where blood tests may not be readily available, RANZCR guidance states “Emergency imaging procedures requiring contrast media
administration e.g. acute stroke, acute bleeding, trauma etc. should not be delayed in
order to obtain renal function testing results prior to the procedure” (refer to RANZCR
page 15).
Metformin Advice
There is no need to stop metformin after administration of contrast media in patients with serum creatinine within the normal reference range and/or eGFR >30.

If the patient's eGFR is unknown or below 30, any metformin medication should be stopped for 48 hours after the contrast examination, and the eGFR re-tested before metformin is resumed (refer to RANZCR page 20).
Other Important Considerations before Cannulation

Cannulae should never be sited within a fistula for the administration of IV contrast media. Patients on dialysis (in particular haemodialysis) are more likely to have a fistula (surgically modified blood vessel) within their arm to aid blood transfer.
Cannulation away from the side of an axillary node clearance is recommended (also referred to as lymph node clearance, lymph node dissection or lymph node
removal) as complications can be more severe if an extravasation was to occur. Lymph node removal is often associated with a history of mastectomy.
Cannulation can sometimes be avoided if the patient presents with a trust
recognised CT safe, PICC Line (refer to Appendix 3). The PICC line must only be
used in conjuction with the Covidien Contrast Injector Pump (see Appendix 6).
Is peripheral cannulation impossible or contraindicated? In exceptional
circumstances, CVP lines/Central lines can be used. Following the flow chart
protocol (Appendix 1) is recommended. NB: a Sodium Chloride 0.9% flush should be carried out after IV contrast media administration.
Does the patient experience difficulties with cannulation?
An arm warmer can sometimes help with cannulation by preventing vasoconstriction. An alarm on the RIS can help draw this to the attention of the team on arrival, to
prevent delays during the scan procedure.
If the patient cannot have contrast or refuses it
It must be documented in the comments section of the examination page on the RIS. The case should be discussed with the duty radiologist before proceeding with the
scan.
16.6.1 The Radiographer must add the following text to the ‘Event Info' section on CRIS if contrast is not possible.
“Your patient was referred for a contrast enhanced CT today; however we were unable to administer contrast because of….(add reason).

This has happened on ….. number of times consecutively. Absence of CT contrast decreases the sensitivity of hepatic lesions and you should consider requesting MRI liver if this is appropriate for your patient.”
Contrast Volumes
Adults (≥ 18 years of age)

For scans that include portal venous abdominal imaging, reference to the volume look-up table should be made (Appendix 7) .This will ensure that contrast is administered to the patients weight thus adhering to the RCR guidelines of best practice.
Other examinations may require fixed volumes (Appendix 8).
Children & Young Adults ( 18 years of age)
17.2.1 Administering 2ml/per 1kg of IV contrast media is recommended for paediatric scans that include portal venous abdominal imaging. This volume calculation is also
recommended for trauma imaging when the patient is
17.2.2 For further advice on contrast media and other unlisted examinations please contact a radiologist/ refer to the manufacture guidelines.
17.2.3 Contrast media volumes must be prescribed and administered by a radiologist (as patients under the age of 18 fall outside the PGD inclusion criteria).
17.2.4 Some Contrast media manufacturers (such as Optiray) do not recommend
administering to children. In these cases, please use an alternative Contrast media such as ‘Visipaque'. Always refer to manufacture guidance or a radiologist for advice if required.
Cannulation
The venflon is the most preferable type of cannula for intravenous contrast.
It is advantageous as it can stay in and can be used for emergency access if a contrast media reaction was to occur.
The injecting radiographer plus one member of staff should always be present. They must both check the dose, expiry date and type of contrast to be injected.
Explain the procedure to the patient and introduce yourself by name and professional title. Wash your hands.
Select an appropriate vein by use of a tourniquet.
The skin should be cleaned using a Chloroprep applicator as per Trust protocol.
Introduce venflon into vein and secure with tape (or IV dressing particularly for long- term and/or in-patient use).
Senior advice should be summoned if there have been two failed attempts at securing intravenous access.

Fill a 5ml/10ml syringe with sodium chloride (NaCl) and expel any air. Connect the saline filled syringe to the venflon and flush. Ensure there is no pain on flushing and check there is no extravasation. The saline should flow with ease.
Inject contrast media and observe the injection site of the patient for any leakage.
If any adverse reaction occurs stop injecting immediately and seek advice
DO NOT remove the venflon. Commence management of adverse reactions to Contrast Media (refer to Appendix 5).
Disconnect contrast tubing from the cannula and secure with a bung.
Note that the entire procedure should observe sterile precautions.
Documentation of the type of contrast media used, the amount, site of injection and flow rate is signed by both radiographers present and scanned as a record on to the RIS.
Management of Contrast Reactions
For immediate management (refer to Appendix 5) for RANZCR guidance.
After the reaction has been documented on the RIS, significant suspected contrast reactions should be investigated appropriately with advice given to the patient.
Extravasations
[Refer to Appendix 4 for Full Guidance]
Immediately stop injection;
Elevate the affected limb;
Apply ice packs to the affected area for a cold compress (found in CT02 refrigerator);
Inform radiologist/doctor supervising injection;
It is the radiologist's responsibility to determine the patients management and follow up;
The extravasation policy must be followed in full (located in: Appendix 4);
Print out the patient advice leaflet.
Waiting times after the administration of CM
The patient should not be left alone or unsupervised in the first five minutes after the injection.
The patient should remain on the premises for at least  minutes post injection.
For patients with an increased risk they should remain on the premises for at least 30 minutes.
Patients should be advised not to drive for one hour following the administration of Contrast media.
Post Procedure

When removing the venflon, the needle must be safely disposed of in the sharps bin. A swab should then be placed on the injection site and pressure should be applied. Pressure should be applied for longer for those patients who are taking anticoagulants including Asprin, warfarin, apixaban or rivaroxiban. When bleeding has stopped, a plaster should then be used to cover the puncture site.
The following advice should be given to the patient/carer. This information is also available on the departmental PGD:
Patients may drink and eat normally (unless specifically told not to);
Continue with any prescribed medication (unless specifically told not to);
The patient should inform a staff member if they experience a warm or cold feeling at the injection site, nausea/vomiting, headache, shortness of breath or a rash;
Outpatients and GP patients should be advised to contact their GP or NHS Direct if they experience any delayed problems.
Document any insertion of cannula in patient notes using the green trust stickers [As per trust protocol].
The radiographer or radiology assistant will ensure the following is recorded on the RIS and must be signed by both radiographers present for the scan:
Date;
Patients' name;
Radiographer and Supervising Radiologists initials;
Contrast media type, volume used and batch number;
Reaction.
Any adverse reactions to contrast media must be recorded in the patient's notes if
available and on the RIS with detail of their nature/Severity/Agent used.  An alarm on the RIS should also be added. All contrast reactions should be recorded in the
radiological report.
Suspected adverse reactions should be reported using the electronic form using the Datix system.
Where possible peel off tracking labels found on vials, syringes or bottles and stick onto the patient record.
Audit and Monitoring
Any issues of non-compliance should be reported to the lead CT radiographers so that any training needs can be quickly resolved.
The radiographer must regularly audit their work, assessing first time accuracy for injections and contrast media reactions, and the management of adverse effects of the examination.
All incidences that have resulted in patient harm or near misses, must be reported on a Datix form. The Datix investigator will review all risk events.
Any immediate training or educational issues relating to lack of compliance with this guideline will be addressed on a one-to-one basis.
Patients who require CT and MRI Contrast
There are occasions when CT and MRI contrast may both be required on the same day. The following advice should be adhered to:
For patients with normal to moderate renal function (eGFR >30) there should be 4 hours between these injections;
For patients with severely reduced renal function (eGFR<30 or on dialysis) there should be 7 days between these injections;
For abdominal CT exams, CT contrast should be given before MRI contrast. For chest and brain examinations, either CT or MRI may be done first.
References

The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists (RANZCR), 2018. Iodinated Contrast Media Guidelineas adopted by the Royal College of Radiologists and Society of Radiographers. Available at: https://www.ranzcr.com/college/document-library/ranzcr-iodinated-contrast-guidelines

Society and College of Radiographers,2015 Course of Study for the Certificationof Competence in Administering Intravenous Injections. Available at: https://www.sor.org/learning/document-library/course-study-certification-competence- administering-intravenous-injections
NHS Choices. Dialysis - How it's performed. 2018 https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/dialysis/what-happens/
Iodinated Contrast Media Guideline - ranzcr.com https://www.ranzcr.com/.../573-iodinated-contrast-guidelines-2016/file

data.text: APPENDIX 2: Patient Questionnaire
CT SCANNING SERVICE PATIENT QUESTIONNAIRE A leaflet on CT scanning is enclosed, which you should read.
Please answer the following questions
Do you suffer from any allergies? Yes / No
Do you suffer from Asthma or Hayfever? Yes / No
Do you have diabetes? Yes / No
Are you taking Metformin (Glucophage) Yes / No
Do you suffer from renal failure or any problem, which might affect the functioning of your kidneys? Yes / No
Do you suffer from any conditions affecting your eyes, such as Glaucoma? Yes / No
Do you suffer from any problems affecting your Heart? Yes / No
Have you had any previous surgery? (If yes, please provide details below) Yes / No For women of childbearing age
Is there any possibility of you being pregnant? Yes / No
On the day of the examination, please bring
Please sign to indicate that you have read and understood these instructions, and to confirm that you agree to have the examination
Name:  Date: Signature:
APPENDIX 3
Using PICC lines
Only trust recognised CT safe CT PICC Lines that have been inserted within Mid Essex Hospitals Trust (MEHT) can be used.
Before the PICC line can be used for the administration of contrast media it MUST:
- Have been inserted in MEHT
- Be a Navilyst Medical PICC line with PASV Valve technology
- Have a purple (body) with
"POWER INJECT 5ml/Sec MAX" written on the body (Double lumen )  OR
“POWER INJECT 3.5ml/Sec MAX” written on the body (Single lumen)
[Picture 1 - Below: Double lumen PICC pressure rated at 5ml/sec MAX with a gauge of 16.5]

data.url: 16031 Administration of IV iodinated contrast media in radiology 2.1.004.jpeg

data.text: [Picture 2 – Below: Single lumen PICC pressure rated at 3.5ml/sec MAX with a gauge of 17]

data.url: 16031 Administration of IV iodinated contrast media in radiology 2.1.005.jpeg

data.text: To use:
Ensure the PICC appears secure at the site (anchored down with dressing) [NB: it is very rare for them to kink]
Use sterile gloves (Universal precautions) [as touching the purple tip can increase the risk of blood borne infection]
A wound-care sterile pack is also recommended (along with sterile drawing up needle, 20ml syringe, bung, sterile wipes + saline)
Scrub the PICC hub/end with a sterile wipe (Avoid touching tip of body with glove)
Draw up in a 20ml syringe 20ml 0.9% NaCl
Aspirate/draw back and look for flashback
Flush line with 0.9% NaCl [Note pt will not be able to feel flushing]
Check that there is no resistance
Keep dressing dry during procedure to keep PICC Line in situ
Injector pump:
Flow rate must NOT exceed the stated flow rate that has been explicitly printed onto the PICC line body
Pressure on the pump is never expected to exceed 200 psi
(Therefore the max PSI on the pump should be set to 200 or less to reduce risk) [NB: The maximum PSI rating for these particular PICC lines is 300psi]
The Covidien power injector pump is to be used for PICC lines as this allows a constant PSI. A maximum PSI level can also be set to reduce risk
After the procedure:
The line must be flushed with 20mls 0.9% NaCl
Need any guidance?
- Phone PICC team/ PICC nurse (Julie Godfrey) if you have any queries in hours on extension 6154 or bleep #1403.
- Phone ITU Nurses if you need any help out of hours on ext 4053
- Interventional Radiologists often have a wealth of experience with PICC lines
- Refer to DRAG protocol on intranet regarding PICC lines
Administration of Intravenous (iv) Iodinated Contrast Media in the Radiology Department/16031/2.1
APPENDIX 4

table_items.text: PROCEDURE: Extravasation of CT & MRI contrast media

data.text: Extravasation of Contrast Media during CT and MRI scans

Extravasation of pharmaceutical products following IV cannulation is a recognised complication. Due to the rates, pressures and volumes involved with contrast media administration it is imperative extravasation is identified and treated early to minimise complications.
The following procedure is in place for the effective treatment and monitoring of extravasation within the CT and MRI department.
Procedure to be undertaken following identification of extravasation
Disconnect patient from injection pump. Leave cannula in situ.
Complete required examination as appropriate
Elevate limb
Apply ice pack to site of extravasation
Contact duty radiologist
Patient injury to be reviewed and assessed by radiologist
If symptoms do not resolve quickly, admit and monitor
Skin blistering, paraesthesia, altered tissue perfusion and increasing persistent pain for more than four hours suggest severe injury is present. If so, seek advice from plastic surgeon.
Record information regarding DATIX ensuring volumes, management of patient and radiologist are consulted are included.
Issue patient information leaflet.
For inpatients only, notify the team responsible and record in notes
Plastic surgeons
Plastic surgeon advice is available on site and should be consulted promptly if treatment does not progress as expected.
Outside of normal working hours

As the duty radiologist is not present outside of normal working hours, this role should be substituted with the responsible attending physician for that patient. The above advice and information should be made available to the responsible physician.
Monitoring
Extravasation rates recorded through DATIX will be monitored yearly. Any significant increases in rate will be investigated.
Reference
The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists, 2018, Iodinated Contrast Media Guidelines V2.3, Australia
APPENDIX 5: MANAGEMENT OF CONTRAST REACTIONS

table_items.text: Supportive measures (antiemetics if prolonged vomiting) Supportive measures Non-sedating antihistamine(s)
Urticaria Bronchospasm or other respiratory symptoms

Non-sedating antihistamine(s) Consider use of adrenaline 1:1000 In adults: 0.1-0.25ml (0.1-0.25mg) intramuscularly into the anterolateral thigh – repeat as necessary In children: 0.01mg/kg intramuscularly up to 0.3mg maximum dose Keep supine; allow patient to sit if dyspnoeic Oxygen by mask (6-10L) Salbutamol or Terbutaline metered dose inhaler (2-3 deep inhalations) In more severe cases give Salbutamol or adrenalin by nebuliser Consider adrenaline Normal blood pressure o In adults: 1:1,000, 0.1-0.5ml (0.1-0.5mg) intramuscularly (use smaller dose in patients with coronary artery disease or elderly patients) o In paediatric patients: 0.01mg/kg up to 0.3mg intramuscularly Decreased blood pressure o In adults: 1:1,000, 0.5ml (0.5mg) intramuscularly o In paediatric patients: 0.01mg/kg

intramuscularly Isolated hypotension Keep supine; elevate patient's legs Oxygen by mask (6-10L/min) Intravenous fluid: rapidly, normal saline or lactated Ringer's solution If unresponsive: adrenaline: 1:1,000, 0.5ml (0.5mg) intramuscularly, repeat as needed Vaso-vagal reaction (hypotension and bradycardia) Keep supine, elevate patient's legs Oxygen by mask (6-10L/min) Atropine o In adults 0.6-1.0mg intravenously, repeat if necessary after 3-5 min, to 3mg total (0.04mg/kg). o In paediatric patients give 0.02mg/kg intravenously (max. 0.6mg per dose) repeat if necessary to 2mg total. o Intravenous fluids: rapid infusion of normal saline or Hartmann's solution 20ml/kg, repeat as necessary
Respiratory or circulatory collapse and/or seizures

Call for resuscitation team Keep supine. Allow patient to sit if dyspnoeic. Suction and maintain airway as needed Oxygen by mask (6-10L), ventilate patient if required. Intramuscular adrenaline into the anterolateral thigh In adults (and in children greater than 25kgs), adrenaline 1:1000 less than 50 kg give 0.25 -0.5mL greater than 50 kg give 0.5mL In children, Adrenaline 1:1,000 1 year 10kg give 0.1mL 3 years 15kg give 0.15mL 5 years 20kg give 0.2mL 8 years 25kg give 0.25mL If necessary, repeat intramuscular dose

every 5 minutes. Large doses of adrenaline may be needed, up to a maximum of 5mL (5mg). In adrenaline resistant cases, especially if the patient has taken beta blocking drugs, consider glucagon 1-2mg intravenous over 5 minutes. If the patient remains shocked after two intramuscular doses, consider an adrenaline infusion to restore blood pressure. Intravenous fluids (e.g. normal saline or Hartmann's solution 20mL/kg); continue as necessary. Additional measures Bronchodilators: for bronchospasm, give salbutamol or via nebuliser or aerosol with spacer device Corticosteroids: Hydrocortisone 2-6mg/kg or Dexamethasone 0.1-0.4mg/kg intravenously Nebulised adrenaline: May be tried for laryngeal oedema (5ml of 1:1000) Supportive measures Observe vital signs frequently; monitor ECG and pulse oximetry Arrange for transfer to hospital if reaction occurs in an outpatient facility Keep under observation for at least 4-6 hours after complete resolution of signs and symptoms, as biphasic reactions may occur
